Despite the spring climate of Paris, he still wears his typical Russian clothes, consisting of a coat with a fur collar, a fur cap, and heavy boots. Buljanoff glances around the lobby, obviously over-whelmed by its magnificence. The Manager, puzzled by Buljanoff's strange appearance, approaches him.

dialogue.raw_text: You are very sure of yourself, aren't you?

dialogue.raw_text: I have heard of the arrogant male in capitalistic society. It is having a superior earning power that makes you like that.

dialogue.raw_text: Russian! I love Russians! Comrade... I have been fascinated by your Five- Year Plan for the past fifteen years!

He is just about to step to the top of the staircase, when suddenly, to his great amazement, he sees Ninotchka, who stands at the balustrade overlooking Paris. Montparnasse... La Boheme... and now I'll show you the greatest attraction! (he steps to a telescope and, taking some money from his pocket, drops a coin in the slot) It will cost me a franc but it is worth it. (he adjusts the telescope) The most wonderful spot in all Paris -- unique! Here, look.... (she looks in telescope) What do you see?

dialogue.raw_text: I see a house that looks like any other house. What's remarkable about it?

dialogue.raw_text: It's not the structure but the spirit which dwells within. There are three rooms and a kitchenette dedicated to hospitality.

dialogue.raw_text: So that is your house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, let's say I live in it. Such a pleasant place... all kinds of comfort, easy to reach, close to street car, bus, and subway...

dialogue.raw_text: I will do my best.

dialogue.raw_text: Well, may I offer you a drink, or how about something to eat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. I've had all the calories necessary for today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do we do now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We take off our hat and coat. (he takes her things) We sit down -- we make ourselves comfortable. We adjust ourselves to the prospect of a most enjoyable evening. We look at each other. We smile. (Ninotchka doesn't respond) Well... we don't smile. How about some music?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that customary?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It helps. It has ever since King David wooed Bathsheba with the harp. As I am not so fortunate as to have my harp at hand, I shall turn on the radio.

dialogue.raw_text: (the observer) I should say this room is eighteen by twenty-five.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not too big and not too small. What I'd call the typical room of an average man. Or shall we say a little above average. Now if there are any special aspects you wish to study I have nothing to conceal. Just look around. That's my desk. Those are my books, and here am I. Where shall we begin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will start with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's great. I'm thirty-five years old. Just over six feet tall. I weigh a hundred and eighty-two pounds stripped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what is your profession?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keeping my body fit, keeping my mind alert, keeping my landlord appeased. That's a full-time job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what do you do for mankind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For mankind not a thing -- for womankind the record is not quite so bleak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are something we do not have in Russia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is why I believe in the future of my country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I begin to believe in it myself since I've met you. I still don't know what to make of it. It confuses me, it frightens me a little, but it fascinates me, Ninotchka.

dialogue.raw_text: Ni-notchka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is correct.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ninotchka, do you like me just a little bit?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your general appearance is not distasteful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at me. The whites of your eyes are clear. Your cornea is excellent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your cornea is terrific. Tell me -- you're so expert on things -- can it be that I'm falling in love with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are bringing in wrong values. Love is a romantic designation for a most ordinary biological, or shall we say chemical, process. A lot of nonsense is talked and written about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I see. What do you use instead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I acknowledge the existence of a natural impulse common to all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What can I possibly do to encourage such an impulse in you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to do a thing. Chemically we are already quite sympathetic.

dialogue.raw_text: (bewildered, and yet completely intrigued) You're the most improbable creature I've ever met in my life, Ninotchka, Ninotchka...

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to say it a thousand times.

dialogue.raw_text: Don't do it, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm at a loss, Ninotchka. You must forgive me if I appear a little old- fashioned. After all, I'm just a poor bourgeois.

dialogue.raw_text: It's never too late to change. I used to belong to the petty bourgeoisie myself. My father and mother wanted me to stay and work on the farm, but I preferred the bayonet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bewildered) The bayonet? Did you really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was wounded before Warsaw.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wounded? How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dumfounded) I'd love to. (she pulls the blouse off her shoulder and shows him her scar) Tsk, tsk, tsk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Polish lancer. I was sixteen.

dialogue.raw_text: Poor Ninotchka. Poor, poor Ninotchka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (readjusting her blouse) Don't pity me. Pity the Polish lancer. After all, I'm alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of a girl are you, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just what you see. A tiny cog in the great wheel of evolution.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're the most adorable cog I ever saw in my life. Ninotchka, Cogitska, let me confess something. Never did I dream I could feel like this toward a sergeant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you hear that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's twelve o'clock.

dialogue.raw_text: It's midnight. One half of Paris is making love to the other half. Look at the clock. One hand has met the other hand. They kiss. Isn't that wonderful?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the way a clock works. There's nothing wonderful about it. You merely feel you must put yourself in a romantic mood to add to your exhilaration.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't possibly think of a better reason.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's false sentimentality.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying desperately to make her mood more romantic) You analyze everything out of existence. You analyze me out of existence. I won't let you. Love is not so simple. Ninotchka, Ninotchka, why do doves bill and coo? Why do snails, coldest of all creatures, circle interminably around each other? Why do moths fly hundreds of miles to find their mates? Why do flowers open their petals? Oh, Ninotchka, Ninotchka, surely you feel some slight symptom of the divine passion... a general warmth in the palms of your hands... a strange heaviness in your limbs... a burning of the lips that is not thirst but a thousand times more tantalizing, more exalting, than thirst?

dialogue.raw_text: You are very talkative.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was that talkative?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, that was restful. Again.

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, my barbaric Ninotchka. My impossible, unromantic, statistical...

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) Glorious, analytical...

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, let it ring.

direction.raw_text: -- LIVING ROOM OF THE ROYAL SUITE It is taken from an ANGLE which includes the door. The lights are still on, the curtains drawn, the empty champagne bottle and glasses litter the room. We hear the buzzer of the corridor door ring several times without an answer.

direction.raw_text: Ninotchka is lying on the bed, still in her evening dress. The diadem is no longer on her head, but no special emphasis is laid on that detail in the camera angle. We hear the sound of the buzzer ringing again and again. Ninotchka half wakens and calls out something which sounds like "come in" without being fully aware of what she is doing.

direction.raw_text: The door is opened from the outside by a maid, who lets in the Duchess Swana, dressed in a smart morning outfit. Swana looks around, surprised and amused at the state of the room. She walks over to the bed where lies Ninotchka, still not enough awake to face reality. Swana is delighted to have surprised Ninotchka in this condition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By now Ninotchka is awake. She gets up and realizes to her acute embarrassment the condition in which Swana has found her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (ironically) Good morning.

dialogue.raw_text: (awakening gradually) What?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know how you feel, my dear. The morning after always does look grim if you happen to be wearing last night's dress. Don't be embarrassed by my presence, though. You couldn't have found anybody more sympathetic to your condition. I remember once in Petrograd when I felt exactly as you do. I had to bow from a balcony to the crowd. My dear, the masses have no understanding of the feelings of a lady before noon. Don't you find that true?

direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into telephone) Operator, will you switch the call please?... Hello?... Darling, your present just arrived.... It's very silly and very wonderful... thank you... No, I won't forget... seven o'clock.... (with great tenderness) Good-by, my darling.... What?... Oh... (softly) salute!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am sorry to have kept you waiting, madame.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : shooting from a HIGH ANGLE. We hear the SOUND of an airplane just taking off. Camera pulls back so that Swana seems to be photographed from the airplane. Finally the SHOT discloses the whole airport and Swana disappearing into the crowd.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: SWANA -- AT THE AIRPORT DISSOLVE TO

direction.raw_text: Swana's maid is opening the door for Swana, who enters in the highest spirits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swana inspects herself briefly in the hall mirror, proceeds into the living room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good afternoon, Jacqueline.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good afternoon, Your Highness. (hesitantly) Madame, I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't find my glove. All right, you're forgiven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Your Highness. Count d'Algout is waiting. He's been here some time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Leon is pacing up and down. Swana enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swana picks up the receiver of the telephone and holds it out to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Leon, darling, how nice! Have you ordered tea or a cocktail?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No thanks, Swana.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did I act stupidly last night? Should I apologize?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the one who should apologize. I should have talked to you before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this, by any chance, going to be a confession?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no, my little Volga boatman. Have you forgotten our First Commandment: Never Complain -- Never Explain. It has worked so often and so perfectly, don't let's break the rule. And please don't look so guilty, otherwise I'll...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This time, Swana -- just this once -- I must ask you to listen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, I'll listen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know you hate the obvious but do you mind if, at this moment, I'm not in the least subtle?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brutal frankness, if you insist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are a hundred ways to approach it, but I feel it can best be said in one simple phrase. I'm in love, Swana.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I thought it was something serious! How could you frighten me so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It must be serious, Swana. Not long ago I'd have considered such a statement rather juvenile and rather middle class. Now I can say it without stammering, without a blush. I'm in love, Swana.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say it over and over again, Leon. Words are a wonderful safety valve, and that's what you need -- because you know it's impossible, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to be simple again, Swana, and you may find it shockingly banal. I've thought it over and I'm willing to take all the consequences, even if it means a complete readjustment of my way of living.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leon! This has the ugly sound of regeneration.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid that's what it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The same old trouble, Leon. You're always late. Whether you're taking me to the Opera or calling for me at a beauty shop, you're never on time. And now, when it's a question of your reform -- late again. (she glances at her wrist watch) By about five minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this, Swana?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Knowing the efficiency of the French Air Service I think I can guarantee that Madame Yakushova has already taken off for Moscow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Has done what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's gone, Leon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you expect me to believe that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here's the telephone. If you call the hotel you will find that you have no seven o'clock appointment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is flying past the Eiffel Tower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- AIRPLANE WINDOW Behind the window we see Ninotchka looking at Paris for the last time. Camera moves over to the next window and we see Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski also giving Paris a sad farewell look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: from the air. The mist has closed in by now so that only the top of the Eiffel Tower is visible above it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -UP -- NINOTCHKA, looking down on the Tower
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Airplane -- Ninotchka, Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski Ninotchka turns from the window and leans against the back of her chair. The Russians follow her example. There is a moment of silence and sadness.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Imagine, for once in our lives we were in Paris and we never went to the Eiffel Tower.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They tell me it has a wonderful restaurant on the second floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: While you eat, you look at the view.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -UP -- NINOTCHKA She is trying to overcome all sentimentality, but as the following speech progresses she cannot escape the personal implication involved.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, it is an amazing piece of engineering. Still the most remarkable iron structure in the world. Leading to the top there is a staircase of over a thousand steps... but an elevator is included in the price of admission.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Camera zooms down on a headline of an article. Mercier buys priceless russian jewels. Russian commission has left for moscow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera follows Leon as he walks excitedly and nervously along the boulevard. He turns into a Russian Intouriste Bureau, one of the travel bureaus maintained by the Soviet government in foreign countries to supply information regarding travel, give visas, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a typical travel bureau. Behind the counter are attendants and some people getting information and pamphlets. Leon enters, looks around, and sees a door which says "Visas and Passport Department." He enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a room smaller than the previous one. Behind the counter stands a typical Bolshevik Official. In front of the counter is an elderly English lady. Leon takes his place behind her, nervous at having to wait. The Official stamps the English lady's passport and hands it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leaves. Leon moves up to the Official.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this moment the telephone rings. The Official takes the receiver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up the receiver. Leon, thinking of Ninotchka, is horrified by this statement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leon, feeling that he has to go to the rescue of his girl, whips up an enormous enthusiasm for the cause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this moment Swana enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Official gasps in surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His words are unmistakably a final dismissal. She walks out. Leon looks after her for a second, then goes back to the Official. He tries to laugh off the incident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Official laughs in a superior way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Official leans forward sarcastically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a knock-out blow, Leon sends him to the floor, then, leaning over the counter, he shouts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He strides out. The Official's head emerges from the counter. As he adjusts his bruised jaw, he speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Establishing Shot of Russia -- First of May -- Stock Shot of May Day Parade on the Red Square
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, everything is in order. I hope you will enjoy your trip to Russia, madame.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. Oh, by the way, I've heard so many rumors about laundry conditions in Russia. Is it advisable to take one's own towels?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly not, madame. That's only capitalistic propaganda. We change the towel every week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Yes... Comrade Cazabine? No, I'm sorry... he hasn't been with us for six months. He was called back to Russia and was investigated. You can get further details from his widow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pardon me, I am very interested in what you just said -- you mean when an envoy goes back to Russia -- if they don't like what he has done they put him out of the way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not always... look at me... I've been back twice. (he knocks on wood)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his alarm growing) Here's my passport.... Please give me a visa. I have to leave for Russia immediately.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading passport) Count Leon d'Algout... a count!... a nobleman!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't hold that against me... please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why should an aristocrat want to go to Russia?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What business?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Private.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is no privacy in Russia. This whole thing seems very suspicious. What's the real reason? If you ever want to get into Russia, take my advice... confess!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dismayed) Confess what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sympathetic to the former Czaristic government -- the White Russians?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On the contrary -- I don't want to have anything to do with them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You believe in our cause?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... I think it's great! Everyone works -- everyone contributes -- that's what I want to do -- work! I make my own bed -- you can call up my butler! I don't believe in the right of the individual. I like the Bolshevik ideal -- everyone being the same. You just like me -- me just like you -- I use your comb -- you use my toothbrush -- oh, it's a great life.... Please... give me that visa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Leon darling!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (startled) Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suavely) After our talk last night I took it for granted that you would drop in here this morning. Knowing how difficult it is to get into Soviet Russia, I thought I might be of some assistance to you. (to the Official) May I introduce myself? I am the Duchess Swana of Russia... another Russia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, please, Swana.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the Official) Count d'Algout was for several years my personal representative and if it is necessary to sign any affidavit for him I'll be delighted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) That does it, Swana. (he leads her toward the door) Now you mustn't miss your appointment with your hair-dresser.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stopping at the door) Just in case they don't give you your visa to Russia I want you to know that I have signed a contract for my memoirs and rented a lovely little chateau in the Touraine, and if you feel the need of a change...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Swana. You are very gracious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She must have her little joke. (the Official responds with a stony look) You're not going to take that seriously.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Grand Duchess Swana... active in the White Russian movement?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Believe me, I have no connection with her any longer... I swear I haven't!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you had!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I want to be absolutely frank with you. I have no business in Moscow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think so too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to see a friend of mine... a very dear friend.... It's a personal matter which has nothing to do with politics or social philosophies.... It's a girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So it's love which drags you to Moscow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No visa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fighting for his point) I must get into that country of yours!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no. No visa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (more aggressively) That's impossible! Nobody has the right.... You can't do that!... If you don't give me that visa...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ironically) You're going to force us... huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (growing violent) Now look here... you advertise all over the world that you want people to go into your country and when someone tries to get in, you keep him out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why should I take a chance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do I know you don't want to blow up a factory?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for... why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or a tunnel or a bridge...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Suspicions... nothing but suspicions!... That's the trouble with you! If you don't let me in I'll stand in front of this office of yours and warn people to keep away from Russia!... I'll picket your whole country....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll boycott you, that's what I'm going to do!... No more vodka... no more caviar... no more Tchaikovsky... no more borscht.... Wait a minute, I know something better than that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you can tell the Kremlin that's just the beginning!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No visa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: March, march, march! Comrades of the World, never has there been such a May Day parade as this! Already for four hours the pavements of Moscow have resounded to the tread of a million boots! Thousands of gun- carriages have thundered past. Thousands of tanks, combined with our mighty air force, have demonstrated to a belligerent neighbor that we are ready and invincible! Now past me marches the great army of our civilians! Men and women of all ages. All servants of the State united in one thought and ideal. Group of Several Units Marching Workmen, soldiers, tanks, airplanes, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Column of Women, dressed in typical Russian May Day parade fashion, marching and saluting. The CAMERA NARROWS DOWN to a CLOSE SHOT OF Ninotchka marching with the others. All her individuality is gone. She is one of many, a cog in the Russian machine. With a stern expression she is looking straight ahead when suddenly something attracts her attention and she glances to one side. A Column of Male Workers is coming in the opposite direction. Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski are recognizable among them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- BULJANOFF, IRANOFF, AND KOPALSKI MARCHING. All three are already pretty exhausted from the long march. Kopalski sees Ninotchka. He whispers it to the others. The three look toward Ninotchka and lift their shoulders with a gesture which says, "Look where we are now."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- NINOTCHKA, answering them with a sad smile. After they have passed she stares straight forward again with the same stern expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- STAIRCASE IN NINOTCHKA'S TENEMENT HOUSE It is an overcrowded house. People are walking up and down stairs, standing grouped in front of the various apartments; children are sliding down the banisters and playing games under the feet of the adults. Ninotchka trudges upstairs wearily. Camera pans with her as she goes into an apartment which is divided into several sub- apartments. Finally she opens the door of her own room and goes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a comparatively small room, which she shares with two other girls. As she enters only one girl is present. It is Anna, a cello player, who sits on the edge of her bed practicing on her cello. Apparently Ninotchka has not adjusted herself completely to the Moscow which she once thought so great.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During the following scene Anna puts her cello in its case and gets ready to go to her job. Ninotchka starts to arrange the table in the center of the floor for a party of four. Out of her cupboard she takes very primitive-looking dishes, a flower pot, glasses, and a kind of shawl which serves as a tablecloth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna is apparently not a fanatical believer in the Bolshevik regime and takes a cynical and humorous attitude toward it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this moment a door to one of the adjoining rooms opens and Gurganov, a middle-aged man with a sour stool-pigeon expression, walks quietly through the room to another door, taking in the girls with one sly glance and giving the impression that not only his eyes but his ears are open. Anna breaks off her remark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks over to her cupboard and takes out a piece of lingerie and comes back to Ninotchka with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ninotchka suddenly is transported to Paris in her memory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna is for a moment speechless over this generous gift. She embraces and kisses Ninotchka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses her again, takes her cello, and starts to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna exits, closing the door. Ninotchka is left alone. Her thoughts are still in the other world, obviously with Leon. Mechanically she looks over the table to see if everything is all right, then she walks over to the radio (a primitive little machine). As she turns the knob she smiles again reminiscently. As she does, the blare of a Russian speech brings her back to reality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quickly she turns the knob and again there is a burst of Russian oratory.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening, Anna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening, Ninotchka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't you late?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, the opera starts an hour later tonight on account of the parade.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you march?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They didn't let me. I am in disgrace. Last week at the performance of Carmen I played a sour note. The conductor got so excited he yelled, "There's sabotage in the string section!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too bad... you missed an inspiring day, Anna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know... my heart is sad... but my feet are happy. When all the tanks and guns were roaring over the Red Square I sat here all by myself and played a Beethoven sonata. Not bad at all. (she has noticed Ninotchka's preparations) Are you expecting someone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A few friends... just a little dinner party.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you serving?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An omelet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled) An omelet! Aren't you living a little above your ration?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I've saved up two eggs and each of my friends is bringing his own so we'll manage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It just goes to prove the theory of our State. If you stand alone it means a boiled egg but if you're true to the collective spirit and stick together you've got an omelet. (devilishly) That reminds me... have you heard the latest they're telling about the Kremlin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) I'll tell you later. (after Gurganov has disappeared into the other room she continues) That Gurganov, you never know whether he's on his way to the washroom or the Secret Police.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should be more careful, Anna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you too, Ninotchka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amazed) About what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ever since you have been back from Paris...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't talked to anyone about Paris. I haven't said a word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's just it. It makes people feel queer. I dont' want you to get in any trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have nothing to hide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should. I'll show you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I passed through the laundry yard today I saw all the women huddled around this so I brought it up here. Things like this create a bad feeling. First they didn't know whose it was. Then they saw the Paris label and did it start a commotion! Some said it's what we all ought to wear and others said it's like hanging foreign ideas on our clothesline. It undermines our whole cause.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (aware of the pettiness which surrounds her) I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know how it is today... all you have to do is wear a pair of silk stockings and they suspect you of counter-revolution.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Anna. I'll dry it up here when I wash it next. I should hate to see our country endangered by my underwear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (confidentially) Ninotchka, you know I am your friend, you can trust me.... Did you bring back anything else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with feeling) No, I left everything in Paris. I just happened to be wearing this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me... what else did you have?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (enjoying the thought) Well, a hat...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was it like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was very silly.... I would be ashamed to wear it here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As beautiful as that? What else? Come, tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An evening gown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled) Evening gown?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A dress you wear in the evening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you wear in the morning?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you get up you put on a negligee, and then you change to a morning frock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean to tell me you wear a different dress for different times of the day?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, Ninotchka, you're exaggerating.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, my dear, it is true. That's how they live in the other world. Here we dress to have our bodies covered... to keep warm....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, sometimes they're not completely covered but... they don't freeze.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fingering the piece of lingerie) They must have wonderful materials to make a thing like this so soft... something you don't even see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You feel it, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hesitantly) Ninotchka, I wouldn't bring this up if we weren't such good friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it, Anna?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know I told you that Pavlov and I are going to get married when he comes back from the maneuvers. Would it be asking too much...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just for the honeymoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can have it for good. It is my wedding present.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ninotchka! Ninotchka!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Am I going to play that cadenza tonight!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Individuals? Yes, as atoms in the cosmos of Soviet Russia. Family? Yes. One great family of one hundred and sixty million, struggling, fighting, victorious Russian proletarians. Thus shall we pursue our way into the future, fists clenched, hearts encased in steel armed against bourgeois sentimentality and...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...From the Exploiters for the Toilers. We are going full steam ahead through industrialization toward socialism. Let us put the Union of Socialistic Soviet Republics into an automobile and the muzhik into a tractor, and then let the capitalists try to keep up with us! The same thing happens for a third time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and thirty million peasants, eighty-five per cent of the population owned three hundred forty-three million four hundred and sixty-nine thousand acres of land, sixty-five per cent of the total area. And one hundred and fifty thousand nobles possessed thirty-five per cent of the country's natural wealth! Ninotchka turns off the radio. She closes her eyes for a moment and with a sad smile murmurs to herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this moment the door opens, and Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski enter. There follow warm greetings between Ninotchka and the Three Russians.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A moment of silence follows. The four look at each other as people do who share a secret.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iranoff and Buljanoff have joined them at the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iranoff unties his egg from his handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands it to Ninotchka. Buljanoff reaches in his pocket and from his expression we see that a catastrophe must have happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The group all go to the gas cooker and Ninotchka starts to make the omelet. The others stand around as though they were watching a great event.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door through which Gurganov disappeared opens and Gurganov comes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The conversation stops. Gurganov walks quietly through the room, again observing everything. He goes out at last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a dead silence. All are again aware of the reality which surrounds. They concentrate quietly on the frying pan.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No music.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ninotchka! Ninotchka!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with great warmth) How are you, you three scoundrels?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wryly) Well, we're back home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sourly) You know what they say -- there's nothing like home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right... and we might as well face it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying not to say what she feels) Come, now, you must not talk that way.... You have to adjust yourselves.... We must be brave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brave... that's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's be happy that we're all alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that's something we owe to Ninotchka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you hadn't given Commissar Razinin such a wonderful report about us, who knows what would have happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can tell you exactly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now let's forget everything except that we're together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (falling in with her attempt) It's a real Paris reunion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you close your eyes and listen to our voices we might be in Paris.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's not close our eyes. There are many good things to see here too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cynically) I think I need my glasses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reprimanding him quietly) A little more tact... look how nicely she's fixed the table -- all for us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in a loud voice, trying to make up for his faux pas) How nicely you've fixed the table, Ninotchka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What a lovely room you have here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many families live here with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only myself and two other girls. One is a cello player in the opera and the other a street-car conductor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impressed) Just three people in a room this size? Whew!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (inspecting the room) And your own gas cooker? That's marvelous! (forgetting himself) Naturally it's not the Royal Suite...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sssh! Once and for all, we're in Moscow!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (walking over to the window) Yes, there's no doubt of that... (sarcastically) Just look out of the window and there it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And it's great! Think what it was a few years ago and what it is now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's right... (under his breath) anyhow let's talk ourselves into it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just see how happy the people look... from here....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you blame them?... at least the May Day parade is over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's another thing... it's spring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The same spring we had in Paris. Just as good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even the swallows are back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, that's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe that's the same swallow we saw in Paris!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is, Ninotchka! It is! He must have been in Paris! You can see it in his whole attitude! He just picked up a crumb of our black bread, shook his head, and dropped it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you asked him why he left France I bet he couldn't name one good reason.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should be a swallow! Right now I would be sitting in front of the Cafe de Paris picking up flakes of French pastry that would melt in my bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, comrades... there is something better in life than crumbs of French pastry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the realist) Yes, a good piece of apfel strudel....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We will get that... we'll get everything... maybe a little bit later but we'll get it... We must be patient... Finally we got the spring, didn't we? We got the swallows, and you will get your apfel strudel too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (consolingly) And if it is too late for you your children will eat it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (breaking the mood) Let's forget the future... let's stop being sentimental... let's start that omelet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. (he takes a little box out of his pocket) Here's my egg. (he hands it to Ninotchka)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And here's mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Comrades... I'm out of the omelet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry... there will be enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come, Ninotchka, let's make it in real Parisian style!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's fill it with confitures, des prunes...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...des raisins de Madere, des framboises... (...with grapes of Madeira, with raspberries...)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...des petites fraises des bois... de la creme de Bretagne... (...with small wild strawberries... with cream...)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...so it blows up that big... what they call an Omelette Surprise!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the surprise is there's nothing in it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, but if we can't put in all these wonderful things at least let's put in some imagination. (he raises his voice) In that one omelet we'll taste the whole of Paris!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (seeing him) Sssh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A man like that... all he has to do is to walk through a room and the omelet drops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The eggs are gradually taking the shape of an omelet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only the last scraps of the omelet are on it. Buljanoff's hand comes in with a big piece of bread with which he sops up every fragment that is left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- NINOTCHKA'S ROOM -- EVENING The curtains are drawn and the lamp lighted. All four are sitting around the table, in the center of which is a samovar. In front of each of them is a glass of tea. One of the Russians is playing a balalaika and all are singing gaily, "Paris." Ninotchka is enjoying their companionship. After a little while the door to the corridor opens and Ninotchka's other roommate, the street-car conductor, strides in. She is a squareset, unfriendly woman in uniform. At sight of her one of the Russians nudges Ninotchka, makes the gesture of ringing up a fare, and accompanies it with an inquiring look. Ninotchka nods. The Russians change their tune quickly to the "Volga Boatman" in order not to awaken animosity. The street-car conductor goes to her bed and starts to take off her shoes and her coat, then draws the curtain. During the following scene we hear the splash of water and the sound of gargling. Again Gurganov crosses the room, this time accompanied by his little son. Suddenly the door is opened by Vladimir, a friendly old man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands her a letter and exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling into the room) Comrade Yakushova, here, the postman left a letter for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- NINOTCHKA She takes the letter, glances at the envelope, and is stunned. She turns the envelope -- an expression of breathless wonder comes over her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ninotchka sits in the chair nearest the lamp. All three are looking over her shoulder. Ninotchka hesitates to open the letter, obviously wanting to read it all by herself. Realizing her feelings, the Three Russians walk to the far end of the room and sit down on a little bench, looking toward Ninotchka with childlike expectancy. In great anticipation Ninotchka opens the letter. She starts to read it. Suddenly her expression changes to one of terrific disappointment. She turns the letter over, glances at the second page, then puts the letter down on the table. The Russians have followed her expression closely. Slowly they walk over to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Iranoff picks up the letter. All three look at it. Insert of First Page of Letter, held in Iranoff's hand. In Leon's handwriting we read: "Ninotchka, my darling," The rest of the writing is blocked out, line by line, and across the page is a big stamp which says "Censored." Iranoff's hand turns the page. The second page is also censored except for the final words, "Yours, Leon."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it, Ninotchka?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's from Paris.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From Paris?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A bill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From Leon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From Leon!... How is he?... Come, tell us... open it... tell us... how is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very sympathetic) Bad news?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look for yourselves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Iranoff puts the letter back on the table. They all understand and realize that Ninotchka wants to be alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ninotchka rises and shakes their hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The three start to leave but Buljanoff returns and whispers to Ninotchka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ninotchka presses his hand. He walks quietly out with the others. Ninotchka, left alone, sits down. She is heartbroken. Her thoughts are too sad and too far away to be disturbed by the snoring which comes from the corner where the street-car conductor has gone to bed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I think it's getting late. Good night, Ninotchka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you for a wonderful dinner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with great warmth) Good night, my friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They can't censor our memories, can they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE WINDOW OF RAZININ'S OFFICE FADE IN

direction.raw_text: -- THE WINDOW OF RAZININ'S OFFICE FADE IN: shooting from the inside. Through the window the background of Moscow. It is winter and snow is on the roofs. The CAMERA PULLS BACK and discloses Razinin sitting at his desk, reading a report with a stern expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- RAZININ'S OFFICE Ninotchka enters carrying several folders. She walks to Razinin's desk and stands waiting for him to recognize her presence. She is a tired, stern girl. Razinin looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ninotchka sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ninotchka has to suppress a smile of amusement at the antics of her three old friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She exits, as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Comrade.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very businesslike) Good morning, Comrade Commissar. Here is my report on the materials available for trading in the next four months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does this include the products of the Far Eastern provinces?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, it does.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you have finished the whole investigation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's marvelous.... You must have worked day and night.... Don't you ever sleep?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need very little sleep. We must be extremely careful what goods we take in exchange. I have already started a survey of our most urgent needs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Comrade, I am afraid you will have to turn over that work to someone else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (startled) May I ask why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please... sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cigarette?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Comrade, have you heard from your friends Kopalski, Buljanoff, and Iranoff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't either, but I've heard about them. You must realize it was only on the strength of your Paris report that I sent them to Constantinople; without that I never would have trusted them on a mission as important as the fur deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May I ask what has happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As soon as our representatives go to a foreign country they seem to lose all sense of balance. If I told you what's going on in Constantinople right now you wouldn't believe it. Those three have been sitting there for six weeks and haven't sold a piece of fur. (he points to the folder) This anonymous report was sent me. They are dragging the good name of our country through every cafe and night club. Here... (he reads from the report) "How can the Bolshevik cause gain respect among the Moslems if your three representatives, Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski, get so drunk that they throw a carpet out of their hotel window and complain to the management that it didn't fly?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, they shouldn't do such things. Are you sure this report is correct?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It gives details which couldn't be invented. Naturally I want to verify it and that's why I need you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (apprehensively) You want me to go to Constantinople?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes... leaving immediately.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (her one object to escape the mission) I appreciate the confidence you show in me, but I must ask you to entrust someone else with this mission. I should hate to interrupt my present work. I am positive that my survey is more important than finding out whether three of our comrades have been drinking some extra glasses of champagne.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (austerely) That is for me to decide, Comrade Yakushova.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am sorry, I don't want to overstep my position -- but please... don't send me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (making a last effort) How can I make myself clear... It is difficult to express but I'd rather not go to foreign countries any more. Please, Comrade... let me stay here... let me finish my work... I am in the rhythm of it now... I don't want to go away. I don't want to be sent into that foreign atmosphere again. It throws one out of gear.... Let me finish my work... I have concentrated everything in it... Please... don't make me go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please don't waste my time, Comrade. Do your duty. Good-by.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will do my best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on a bright sunlit day, if possible with the circling shadow of an airplane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- AIRPORT IN CONSTANTINOPLE, shooting from an airplane angle. A crowd is awaiting the arrival of a plane. The CAMERA goes down to a CLOSE SHOT of Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski, standing in the crowd. All three are very elegantly and gaily dressed. They are in the happiest mood. One of them carries a large bouquet of flowers to greet Ninotchka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Its style should suggest the locale. Ninotchka enters with the Three Russians, who are very happy to have her with them again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ninotchka protests, but during the whole scene it is evident that behind her protestations there is none of the force and conviction she displayed in a similar situation in the Royal Suite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ninotchka looks toward the balcony and is dumbfounded as she sees Leon standing there smiling at her. He walks quietly toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leon takes her hand and kisses it. The Three Russians exchange glances. The CAMERA PANS WITH THEM --leaving Ninotchka and Leon as Russians walk discreetly out of the room and close the door behind them.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: LIVING ROOM OF A VERY LUXURIOUS HOTEL SUITE IN CONSTANTINOPLE

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating the room) How do you like it, Ninotchka? Isn't it wonderful?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell us... tell us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Buljanoff, Iranoff, Kopalski...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, please, Ninotchka, don't start figuring it out in cows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've done it again and I am responsible. How can you forget yourselves this way? You were sent here to make money, not to spend it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Buljanoff, she still has those old- fashioned Bolshevik ideas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is high time you got out of Russia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not knowing what to do with the three rascals) I must be stern with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (delighted) That's our old Ninotchka!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (agreeing with him) Yes, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't forget, the day will come when you will have to face Razinin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cockily) Good old Razinin! Is he still alive? How does he manage?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But, Comrades...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with the happiness of being free again in his voice) We are not comrades any more... we are friends, Ninotchka.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Imagine, we don't have to whisper any longer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can say whatever we want. We can shout... we can complain... Look... (he opens the door leading to corridor) The service in this hotel is terrible! (he closes the door) See? Nobody comes... nobody pays any attention. That's freedom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) No, that's bad management.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it possible to bring you back to reality for a moment? I must have a complete report of your negotiations and a detailed expense account.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't ask for it, Ninotchka. There is a Turkish proverb which says, "If something smells bad, why put your nose in it?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And there is a Russian saying: "The cat who has cream on his whiskers had better find good excuses."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With our cream situation what it is, it is Russia which should apologize to the cats.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (helplessly) Friends... friends, Buljanoff, Iranoff...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (afraid of being left out) ...and Kopalski.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleadingly) Don't make it difficult for me. This is no more a pleasure trip for me than it is for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was our idea when we first came. All we thought we would get out of this trip was a Turkish bath, but... we learned better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ninotchka, we are in the magic East, the country of Aladdin and His Lamp...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves... into one single hour you can crowd a thousand and one nights.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All you have to do is say "open sesame."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know how I can get you out of it this time. How will it end? What will happen to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (intimately) Shall we tell her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (proudly) Ninotchka, I hope you'll be our guest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Guest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have opened a restaurant...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...we have a wonderful electric sign: "Dine With Buljanof, Iranoff, and Kopalski."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you are deserting Russia?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing the song of freedom) Don't call it desertion. Our little restaurant... that is our Russia... the Russia of borscht, the Russia of beef Stroganoff, blinis with sour cream...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...the Russia of piroshki... people will eat and love it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are not only serving good food, we are serving our country... we are making friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (completely bewildered) Who gave you this idea? What is responsible for all this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a gleam in his eye) There's something in Constantinople... something irresistible....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...it is in the air... it may come around the corner as you walk down the street....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...it may step out of a bazaar... it may wait for you in a corridor... it may hide in the shadow of a minaret....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing to the balcony) Right now it's on the balcony.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking longingly at Ninotchka) They wouldn't let me in so I had to get you out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still taken aback) So -- you're behind all this. I should have known.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- LEON AND NINOTCHKA LEON Trying to keep me away from you! It couldn't be done. Naturally I couldn't go on forever punching passport officials in the nose -- but I found a way, didn't I? Darling, I had to see you. I wrote and wrote but all my letters came back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ninotchka is aware that she is facing a decision. She knows what she wants but still tries to evade a definite answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leon takes her in his arms, they kiss as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The one I got they wouldn't let me read. (carried away by emotion) It began, "Ninotchka, my darling," and ended, "Yours, Leon."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with great feeling and sincerity) I won't tell you what came between... I'll prove it. It will take a long time, Ninotchka... at least a lifetime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But, Leon, I am only here for a few days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you don't stay with me, I'll have to continue my fight. I'll travel wherever Russian commissions are. I'll turn them all into Buljanoffs, Iranoffs, and Kopalskis. The world will be crowded with Russian restaurants. I'll depopulate Russia. Once you saved your country by going back. This time you can save it by staying here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, when it is a choice between my personal interest and the good of my country, how can I waver? No one shall say Ninotchka was a bad Russian.
dialogue.name: dialogue
